results.title: Divorce can happen to the nicest people
results.creator_credit: Stephen Smallwood, Consolidated Productions and Paternoster Nominees
results.brief_description: Peter Mayle, author of successful children’s information books such as “Where did I come from?”, examines the issue of divorce in an attempt to reassure children about the anxieties they may be facing in their own lives. The program is geared towards making children understand that divorce is not the end of their family; focusing on why couples fall in and out of love; what happens to parents when they separate and how the family must cope with new responsibilities. The program seeks to comfort children who may be blaming themselves for the family breakup. Animated and simply narrated, this program is more suited to middle primary school children and above.
results.title_for_label: Divorce can happen to the nicest people

results.title: Doc: a Portrait of Herbert Vere Evatt, 1894-1965
results.creator_credit: Pat Fiske, Denise Haslem, Film Australia, National Film and Sound Archive of Australia and David McKnight
results.brief_description: Known as “the Doc”, Evatt was an idealist, internationalist, a lawyer and a politician. He was the only Australian elected as President of the United Nations (1948) and the decisions he handed down as a High Court Judge had lasting effects on the course of Australian political history. Evatt fought to defeat an attempt to ban the Communist Party, only to find that his own party, the Australian Labor Party was deeply divided on the issue and his contentious role in 1950’s politics overshadows his many notable achievements. This excellent documentary blends commentary, newsreel footage and interviews with historians, family and public figures to offer a rare and moving insight into the life of one of Australia’s most notable political figures.
results.title_for_label: Doc: a Portrait of Herbert Vere Evatt, 1894-1965

results.title: Division of human tumor cells = Teilung von menschlichen tumorzellen
results.creator_credit: H. Lettre and Institut für Film und Bild
results.brief_description: The film shows human tumour cells which have been removed from a patient with carcinoma of the stomach. The cells are contained in the ascitic fluid drawn off from the patient and are observed in this fluid for several hours after removal. A phase-contracts microscope is used with a magnification of 900 times. The conditions for the continued growth and division of the cells are not the most favourable and, in general, only preparations for divisions are observed. However, a normal cell division has been recorded and also a case of tetra-polar division. Silent, with captions in German.

results.title: Diving: no place for cowards
results.creator_credit: Gary Toole, Jacques Bobet and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The top of a ten-meter diving tower is no place for cowards, according to Jim Lambie, the vociferous coach of two of Canada’s top female divers, Janet Nutter and Linda Cuthbert. In this film we see what goes into making a champion performer and the complete faith and loyalty the athletes have towards Lambie despite his brusque manner. A highlight of the film is the close diving competition at the 1978 Commonwealth Games in Edmonton.

results.title: Divided we stand
results.creator_credit: Rizu Hamid, Olga Edridge and BBC
results.brief_description: What was expected to be the formation of a “New Germany”, representing features of both the East and the West, has not occurred with re-unification. This program examines the problems and the disappointments that East Germans have had to confront since re-unification.

results.title: Divided trail: a Native American odyssey
results.brief_description: Uses archival footage and stills to document the beginnings of the American Indian protest movement in Chicago during the 1970s. Three leaders of the movement recount the events which motivated them to bring public attention to the plight of the American Indian, who has left the reservation with promises of employment and a better life only to find unemployment, slums and alcoholism.

results.title: Distant islands
results.creator_credit: Bettina Maylone, Jack Long and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: As in her previous film, the award-winning The Hometown, the filmmaker has used applique and embroidered tapestries to animate a story from her childhood. Distant Islands recalls a young girl’s happy summers spent sailing with her family off the coast of British Columbia. Each tapestry, meticulously stitched by hand with brightly colored yarns, evokes a memory of leisurely days at sea, drifting among the islands.

results.title: Perception structure or flow (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bob Nichol and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Seeing is believing, and believing is seeing, says this film, in an engaging, involving exanimation of what perception is - what causes one person to see things one way, another person in a totally different way. A film to stimulate discussion, especially in the classroom at senior levels.

results.title: Peoples of the Skeena
results.creator_credit: James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The Getikshan and Tsimshian Indians of northern British Columbia live in two worlds. Against the mountains and forests tower the ancient totem poles; the old graveyards reveal past history; on the reserves the traditional crafts are still practised. But in the school games, in the wedding complete with white veil and white rice, and in the sawmill we see how other ways are being adopted. As climax, the film shows the action-packed rodeo at Kispiox.

results.title: People on Sunday
results.creator_credit: Edgar G. Ulmer, Robert Siodmak and Filmstudio
results.brief_description: This pioneering low-budget film made at the very end of the silent era, was an avant-garde blend of feature and documentary. Its lyrical recording of the streetlife of everyday Berlin owes something to the cycle of ‘city symphony’ films popular in the mid-Twenties. Onto this documentary background is grafted a simple narrative focusing on the interactions between five young Berliners—all played by non-professional actors—who spend a typical Sunday together in and around Berlin. The film launched the careers of all six principal filmmakers involved, and had a huge influence on subsequent film movements including the French New Wave, Italian Neorealist and British Free Cinema movements. This restored version contains important scenes previously missing and features a new score by Elena Kats-Chernin. Written by Billie Wilder, Curt Sidomak and Robert Sidomak. Photography, Eugen Schufftan and Fred Zinnemann. Based on an original story by Curt Siodmak.
